title: 1616-B
statement: B. Mirror in the Stringtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou have a string $$$s_1 s_2 \\ldots s_n$$$ and you stand on the left of the string looking right. You want to choose an index $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le n$$$) and place a mirror after the $$$k$$$-th letter, so that what you see is $$$s_1 s_2 \\ldots s_k s_k s_{k - 1} \\ldots s_1$$$. What is the lexicographically smallest string you can see?A string $$$a$$$ is lexicographically smaller than a string $$$b$$$ if and only if one of the following holds:$$$a$$$ is a prefix of $$$b$$$, but $$$a \\ne b$$$;in the first position where $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$ differ, the string $$$a$$$ has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in $$$b$$$.InputThe first line of input contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 10\\,000$$$): the number of test cases.The next $$$t$$$ lines contain the description of the test cases, two lines per a test case.In the first line you are given one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq 10^5$$$): the length of the string.The second line contains the string $$$s$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ lowercase English characters.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case print the lexicographically smallest string you can see.ExampleInput4 10 codeforces 9 cbacbacba 3 aaa 4 bbaaOutputcc cbaabc aa bbNoteIn the first test case choose $$$k = 1$$$ to obtain "cc".In the second test case choose $$$k = 3$$$ to obtain "cbaabc".In the third test case choose $$$k = 1$$$ to obtain "aa".In the fourth test case choose $$$k = 1$$$ to obtain "bb".

You are given a string of lowercase English letters. You can place a mirror at any position in the string.  The mirror reflects the portion of the string to its right. What is the lexicographically smallest string you can see after placing the mirror?

Lexicographically smallest means the string that comes first alphabetically. 

**Input:**

* The first line contains the number of test cases.
* Each test case has two lines:
    * The first line contains the length of the string.
    * The second line contains the string.

**Output:**

* For each test case, print the lexicographically smallest string you can see after placing the mirror.
You are given a string. You can place a mirror at any position in the string.  What is the smallest possible string you can see after placing the mirror, considering the reflection?
